docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: A July 6 Week in Review article describes how tax breaks for certain constituencies can be used as social engineering. But you fail to mention that tax penalties are also used for this purpose.

headline.main: I.R.S. Tax Code Is Used to Discriminate, Too

docs.lead_paragraph: Hercules can lift many things: houses, mountains, tree trunks. But so far he has been impotent at his most important task: hoisting the Walt Disney Company's stock price.

headline.main: Hercules Is Too Weak to Lift Disney Stock

docs.abstract: Market Place column on prospects for Walt Disney Co's stock in light of weak performance of its animated film Hercules and turmoil at its ABC television network; drawing (L)
docs.snippet: Hercules can lift many things: houses, mountains, tree trunks.     But so far he has been impotent at his most important task: hoisting the Walt Disney Company's stock price.

docs.lead_paragraph: The administrator of an insurance program for employees of Paterson pleaded guilty yesterday to defrauding the city by filing $680,000 in duplicate claims, prosecutors said. Joseph Egan was the president of Capital Administrators, a defunct company that ran self-insurance pools. Such systems became popular in the 1990's as municipalities tried to avoid skyrocketing health care premiums. Employees' insurance claims are paid directly from a pool of money collected from the public and private organizations enrolled.
docs.abstract: Joseph Egan, administrator of health insurance program for employees of Paterson, NJ, pleads guilty to defrauding city by filing $680,000 in duplicate claims (New Jersey Daily Briefing) (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: The hailstorm that did so much damage to roofs here a little more than a year ago pulled Antonio Rodriguez into the labor force. Kneeling on the lawn in front of a white clapboard home recently, he cut strips of asphalt shingles while four other young men lugged the shingles up a ladder and nailed them in place. Soon after, the team moved on to the next damaged roof. Mr. Rodriguez, traveling from Mexico, settled here five years ago, but making a living came hard. Stints as a day laborer alternated with longer periods of idleness in which he rarely even looked for a job. ''My friends offered me work sometimes,'' he said. And then the hailstorm, and the prospering Kentucky economy, brought Mr. Rodriguez full blast into the labor force.

headline.main: U.S. Job Machine Absorbing Fresh Workers

docs.abstract: United States labor force, composed of everyone working or actively seeking work, has been growing rapidly for 18 months and continues to grow faster than working-age population; four million more workers have joined growing economy since start of 1996, many of them Hispanics, younger women and men over 55; most are entering at relatively low pay, drawn into labor force by employers offering more than minimum wage; companies are recruiting among those ignored in past; graphs; map; photos (L)

docs.lead_paragraph: A Texas hospital, owned by the nation's second-largest for-profit chain, agreed today to police its doctors for drug and alcohol abuse and to ask the state Legislature to review laws that keep secret the disciplinary procedures imposed against doctors. The agreement came in a $9.5 million malpractice settlement that experts said could make hospitals more responsible for weeding out incompetent doctors, rather than relying on licensing boards to do it.

headline.main: Hospital Will Check Doctors for Drug Abuse

docs.abstract: South Park Hospital and Medical Center in Lubbock, Tex, agrees to police its doctors for drug and alcohol abuse and to ask State Legislature to review laws that keep secret disciplinary procedures imposed against doctors; agreement comes in $9.5 million malpractice settlement that experts say could make hospitals more responsible for weeding out incompetent doctors; in settlement, South Park and Dr Jack Dunn 3d, anesthesiologist with history of drug abuse, admitted to their roles in botched delivery that led to death of Margo Glickman Johnson and her unborn child (M)
docs.snippet: A Texas hospital, owned by the nation's second-largest for-profit chain, agreed today to police its doctors for drug and alcohol abuse and to ask the state Legislature to review laws that keep secret the disciplinary procedures imposed against...

docs.lead_paragraph: With a new push from President Clinton, House and Senate negotiators meet on Thursday in the first of many sessions intended to wrap up agreement this month on legislation to balance the Federal budget and help preserve Medicare for millions of baby boomers. Then on Friday, lawmakers from the two chambers will start ironing out their differences on a tax bill, which was described today by Senator Tom Daschle of South Dakota, the Democratic leader, as ''probably the single most important piece of legislation'' in this Congress.

headline.main: President Gives Nudge To Deal on Budget Bill

docs.abstract: House and Senate negotiators, with new push from Pres Clinton, will meet on July 10 in first of many sessions intended to wrap up agreement on legislation to balance Federal budget; summary of some important issues on which House and Senate disagree (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: A new study has found that stroke victims in health maintenance organizations are more likely to go to nursing homes and less likely to go to costlier rehabilitation centers than similar patients with traditional insurance. The study, led by Dr. Sheldon M. Retchin of Virginia Commonwealth University in Richmond, was published in the Wednesday issue of The Journal of the American Medical Association. Citing other studies, the researchers say that the difference in care might affect the ability of the victims to live on their own again.
docs.abstract: Study by Virginia Commonwealth University researcher finds stroke victims in health maintenance organizations are more likely to go to nursing homes and less likely to go to costlier rehabilitationn centers than similar patients with traditional insurance (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: TRAVEL may be broadening, but a recently published study of World Bank employees strongly suggests that travel to foreign lands on business may be hazardous to one's health. Based on a study of insurance claims filed in 1993 by 4,738 staff members and consultants of the Washington-based bank, Dr. Bernhard Liese, director of the bank's internal health services department, and four other researchers recently found that business travelers file medical claims at a greater rate than stay-at-homes. And for many categories of diseases, but especially infectious diseases and psychological disorders, the rate of claims increases with frequency of travel.

headline.main: A study indicates there may be more to travel illness than jet lag and infectious diseases.

docs.abstract: Recently published study of World Bank employees strongly suggests that travel to foreign lands on business may be hazardous to one's health; study finds that business travelers file medical claims at greater rate than stay-at-homes; Ministry of Tourism of the Bahamas is sponsoring a Weather Conference for July 17-20 in Nassau with intention of bringing more candor to issue of impact of hurricanes on the Bahama Islands; Zagat will publish its biennial survey of US hotels, resorts and spas; winner of best hotel is Mansion on Turtle Creek in Dallas, Tex; British Airways will operate eight nonstop flights to Britain from Kennedy International Airport; but because of three-day strike scheduled to start at 1 AM on July 9, it has canceled four flights--two from Kennedy to London's Heathrow, one from Kennedy to Gatwick and one from Newark to Heathrow (L)

docs.lead_paragraph: Dow Sets Another Record, Rising by More Than 100 The Dow Jones industrial average hit its 32d record close of the year and its first above 7,900. It surged 103.82 points, or 1.32 percent, to 7,962.31, as investors remained optimistic about corporate profits and a stable economy. Broader market indexes also set records, with the Standard & Poor's 500 rising 6.55 points, to 918.75, and the Nasdaq composite index increasing 14.36 points, to 1,485.10. The Dow was bolstered by heavy demand for cyclical issues, like International Paper -- which announced that it planned to cut its work force and sell assets -- as well as Caterpillar and Du Pont. $(Page D6.$)

docs.lead_paragraph: IT has long been known that international business travel poses health risks like exposure to infectious diseases. However, business travelers are also three times as likely to suffer psychological problems as their stay-at-home colleagues, a recent study by the World Bank has found. The study, in the July issue of Occupational and Environmental Medicine, was based on medical insurance claims made in 1993 by the nearly 5,000 business travelers among the bank's 11,000 staff members, including long-term consultants. They make about 18,000 international business trips a year.
docs.abstract: World Bank study suggests business travelers are three times as likely to suffer psychological problems as their stay-at-home colleagues (S)
